results.title: In Praise of Quarantine Clapping
results.abstract: The highlight of my day — every day — is opening my window and yelling at the sky.

results.title: Lessons in Constructive Solitude From Thoreau
results.abstract: The writer used his self-quarantine at Walden to pursue an intensive course in self-education. In the present pandemic moment, there’s plenty to learn from standing still.

multimedia.caption: Walden Pond, where Henry David Thoreau settled in semi-seclusion for nearly two years while working on his journals and on “Walden; or, Life in the Woods.”

results.title: Angry Fans Say First the Concerts Were Canceled, Then the Refunds
results.abstract: Ticket vendors are being criticized for treating the thousands of live events that were called off as postponements, on which some do not offer refunds.
results.byline: By Ben Sisario and Graham Bowley

multimedia.caption: The emptied stages of concert venues around the world have disappointed fans who bought tickets for shows that have been postponed and who now say they can’t obtain refunds.

results.title: The Coronavirus Derails Marina Abramovic’s Maria Callas Opera
results.abstract: “7 Deaths of Maria Callas” should have been the culmination of a 60-year obsession. Now its future is uncertain.

results.title: ‘Modern Family’ Goes In for a Group Hug
results.abstract: After 11 seasons, the ABC comedy ended its Emmy-winning run with a bunch of new beginnings. The creators talked about the emotional finale and the added resonance of having it air during quarantine.

multimedia.caption: “We always tried to be a happy show,” said the “Modern Family” co-creator Steve Levitan, left, with the cast members Julie Bowen, Ty Burrell and Nolan Gould (far right).

results.abstract: With views of the water, skyline, bridges and piers, the promenade encapsulates New York’s history. Our critic walks with the architect Deborah Berke.

results.title: Broadway Will Remain Closed at Least Until June, and Probably Longer
results.abstract: The 41 Broadway theaters have been closed since March 12, and industry leaders are aware that large gatherings may be among the last forms of activity to resume when the pandemic eases.

multimedia.caption: The streets of New York’s theater district, ordinarily packed with people and traffic, have been largely empty since the coronavirus pandemic forced the closing of theaters and most stores and restaurants.

results.title: John Prine’s 15 Essential Songs
results.abstract: He showed how much humor you could put in a song and still be taken seriously. The singer and songwriter died of complications of Covid-19 at 73.

results.title: Overlooked No More: F.N. Souza, India’s Anti-Establishment Artist
results.abstract: Souza, who started a collective of renegade artists in 1947, embraced the sacred and profane in erotically charged images. Several of his paintings fetched record auction prices for Indian art.

multimedia.caption: F.N. Souza in London with one of his paintings in 1955. After India gained its independence from Britain, he sought to create a “new art for a newly free India.”
multimedia.copyright: Thurston Hopkins/Picture Post/Hulton Archive/Getty Images; Estate of F.N. Souza. All rights reserved, DACS/ARS 2020 (artwork)

results.title: Christie’s to Pay up to $16.7 Million Fine Over Tax Violations
results.abstract: The penalty is part of a settlement to avoid prosecution by the Manhattan district attorney’s office, which said the auction house did not properly collect New York sales taxes.

multimedia.caption: Christie’s has been cooperating with investigators from the Manhattan district attorney’s office into how overseas affiliates handled state and local sales tax collection.

results.title: Ronald Lewis, Preserver of New Orleans Black Culture, Dies at 68
results.abstract: His colorful museum, the House of Dance and Feathers, was a monument to the rich street culture of African-Americans.

results.title: A Designer Whose Home Is as Fanciful as Her Plaster Creations
results.abstract: Viola Lanari’s maximalist London apartment, which is filled with enchanting objects that include her own handcrafted lamps and tables, has the feel of a small museum.

multimedia.caption: “I’m building my own little museum,” says Lanari of her maximalist, object-filled home. The living-room door was decorated by the stylist Maude Smith in the painterly style of Charleston, the country retreat of the Bloomsbury Group in Sussex, England.

results.title: Mort Drucker, Master of the Mad Caricature, Is Dead at 91
results.abstract: His illustrations of celebrities for Mad magazine’s movie and television satires inspired countless cartoonists. Actors, politicians and others knew they had made it when he drew them.

multimedia.caption: Mort Drucker joined Mad magazine in 1956 and illustrated his last movie parody in 2008. “I think I’ve drawn almost everyone in Hollywood,” he once said.

results.title: In Italy, Coronavirus Books Rush to Publication
results.abstract: Doctors, novelists and other writers are exploring, as quickly as they can, the pandemic’s impact on a country that was among its earliest victims.
des_facet: How Contagion Works: Science, Awareness and Community in Times of Global Crises (Book)

multimedia.caption: Paolo Giordano in 2018. His new book, “How Contagion Works,” is intended as a record of his experience during the coronavirus outbreak in Italy. “I don’t want to lose what the epidemic is revealing about ourselves,” he writes.
